intro: Fumaria bastardii var. major, commonly known as the greater celandine, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Papaveraceae family. It is characterized by its basal rosette of elongated, lobed leaves and produces clusters of bright yellow flowers in late spring to early summer. The plant is native to Europe and parts of western Asia, often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. It contains various alkaloids and has been used historically in traditional medicine. Its botanical features make it easily distinguishable from other members of the genus Fumaria.
